author: cian riordan
content: Agreed -- be critical of everything. Be critical of things that are expensive for the sake of being expensive. Things that are just  instagram ads shilling to newbies. Critical of  Greg Wells pandering to whatever his base is. But recommending a 4k converter based on 'audible conversion quality' isn't helpful if the consumer doesn't have a million other ducks in a row first -- room treatment, adequate monitoring, proper gainstaging, etc. Jon has that figured out, so it makes sense for him. But when people come into a forum with questionable knowledge and background in music production asking what's the best converter, I think it's fair to ask some prying questions before just making blanket recommendations on what one person heard or not. I have plenty of semi-OK stuff that still gets used on the regular, and plenty of expensive gear that I would happily toss out of my workflow. They're all just tools. And whether its bougie DW Fearn or a black-friday Acustica plugin, , if it works for your workflow and gets you results you're happy with, then its worth whatever money you're willing to pay for it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hey. Welcome! 

Based on what you've shared, it sounds like you're early in your journey making records. There are a lot of reasons that an Apollo might be a good investment, but buying them for the converters probably isn't the best use of your money at this stage.

The difference that converters will make (if any) is very very small compared to other factors. Factors like having a good room to listen in, acoustic treatment for the room, and the monitors you're listening through. I would prioritize those and consider converters to be very low priority until you get those other factors working well.

So unless there are other reasons that you'd like to have an Apollo I think you can save your money for the time being.

author: Zack Hames
content: I’ve honestly not ever been able to just “get used to” a shitty monitoring situation. I tried to convince myself of that by using the same pair of Yamaha HS80m’s for years, and somehow never liked my mixes. Got new, better monitors and better treatment and my mixes got better. author: Eric Martin
content: I’d echo what’s been said but I’d also add that you should play with the tuning of the batter and reso head to get the sound, you might be surprised to hear that tighter might actually deliver more low tone and overtone to the mic than the puff of air that a too loose head will deliver, I’d also mess with the dampening material, start with less dampening and only dampen what it needs to tame the basketball ping if you get that tone. And let the beater rebound don’t bury the beater, imagine the kick drum is a guitar string and burying the beater is like playing with a piece of foam killing the resonance. play with all these things and you’ll get more low end

author: peterlabberton
content: I’m sure you’ve read this or could find it with a quick google search, but starting with the first reflection points would be my first step. Side walls next to the listening position and ceiling above. Then probably behind the listening position and perhaps behind the speakers. If you have anything to use as a bass trap, I’d recommend using something like fuzzmeasure to shoot the room and experiment with placing that stuff in different places. You’ll be able to see peaks and valleys moving around in the low end, assuming what you’re using is actually effective at sucking up bass. There are people with much more knowledge than me, but that’s where I’d start!

author: Rob Domos
content:
If it’s the hissing kind of noise that you get more of when you switch from condensers to dynamics and ribbons, then it’s not the kind of noise that is coming from the room. 

In rooms the main things you would be concerned about would be reflection (which you fix with treatment) and mechanical noise from things like computer fans, clocks, etc. and condenser mics would pick those kinds of sounds up more, not less. 

Any unison pre in the Apollo should be plenty low noise to not bother you on your condenser mics. I agree with others that not using any unison pre will make the noise floor lower, but I disagree with them in that I think using the unison pres is a pretty good idea often. 

That said, if you’re struggling with noise, definitely try not compressing on the way in because compressors are only going to raise the noise floor. 

On dynamic mics and ribbon mics, you can decrease your noise floor pretty considerably by picking up a cloudlifter and throwing that in the chain. 

If you do all of the above and still have a high noise floor then either the Apollo is broken (which is pretty unlikely), or your microphone is picking up mechanical noise from your air conditioning, computer fan, refrigerator, etc. if those are the issue, then tackle the issue there. Turn off the A/C, turn off the fridge, turn off the LED lights, etc and see what you hear.

author: tinkerjef
content:
hi all, new guy here, and I guess I have a pretty simple question, and might be kinda loaded, but what does absolute phase shift sound like?

Ive been learning a heck of a lot from the LWMR series on yt, and I've been approaching my mixing philosophy from the lens of an electronics designer.

It's pretty well accepted in the electronics/audio research world that absolute phase shifts aren't really audible, and that the moment audio is played in a space that has reflections, it's imperceptible. The only real way to hear a phase shift is to be in an anechoic chamber and play a specialized test signal (like a sine wave with timed phase shift pulses to create a slight warble)

I get how on individual tracks if you EQ something, the phase shift can affect how that track interacts with another track when summed, but I often hear that for example, Jon puts a 16k boost then a 27k low pass on the master that creates a phase bump that he likes. Which theoretically shouldn't be audble... Shouldn't it be some other reason like the VT5 saturating a special way?

author: spectrummasters
content:
I expect this will be common knowledge to the vets but might be new to others (as it is to me ) and thought it looked a fascinating technique im going to try and wanted to share :

I just watched Steve albini describe how he would use an equalizer in a feedback loop to generate a resonant frequency, then blend that tone with the original kick drum signal to allow him to choose a complementary pitch/note with the eq and via the feedback loop also add sustain to taste . 
If others know a better routing please do correct me : i think he sent the kick to the eq as an aux (not an insert), then brings the return back in a new channel , then sends that channel back to the eq again, creating the feedback loop and blends that into the mix to support the untreated kick. 
I feel this is a little different to regular ITB parallels or VOG processing in that he’s creating a feedback loop/resonance at a chosen note …sort of like synthesising an 808 ? Kinda genius. 
(This is happening OTB with hardware )
